title: What would happen to life on earth if earth had several moons? - Quora

response.answer_text: Who says we don't have more moons? A definition of "moon" according to the OED, says that it is any "natural" object orbiting a planet. Currently, there is a "mystery" object orbiting Earth, temporarily designated 9U01FF6, with an orbital distance between 50,000 and 460,000 miles and an orbital period of about 31 days. It is a mystery since its origins or makeup is unknown, but is probably only about 2 or 3 meters in diameter. Not really that big, is it? Mars, which is roughly half the size of Earth, has 2 moons, Phobos and Deimos. They are small, probably captured asteroids. Pluto, technically no longer classified a planet, has 5 identified moons. The answer to this question really depends on size. Is it possible for us to have more moons? Absolutely. If we make this a "what if" where a second moon of around the size of our current one, and simplify the physics by saying they are in a complimentary orbit with each other (basically the same orbital periods, avoiding a collision in the near future), several things would happen. The interior of the Earth would be much hotter than it is now, due to the tidal forces. this means the tectonic plates would move much faster, mountain ranges would be much higher, Volcanoes would be more numerous and more active, releasing more sulphur, carbon dioxide and other toxic gases into the atmosphere, but also much more dust. Earthquakes would be more frequent, and of a greater magnitude. Earth's surface would be much colder, based on the history of past large eruptions. The Earth's magnetic field would be much stronger due to a more active core. This would translate into spectacular Auroral displays and decreasing the amount of solar and cosmic radiation from reaching the surface. The tidal action would continually churn the oceans, making the coastal tides much higher and would erode the coasts much faster. On this colder Earth, the oceans would continually ice over, only to be broken up cyclically. If this ice is not given a chance to melt, eventually the oceans would almost completely freeze over. Assuming the big freeze or volcanic gasses don't prevent life from evolving to greater complexity, extinction events caused by large asteroids would be less likely, with both moons sweeping our vicinity of objects better than it does now. The diversity of life would be greater, but with organisms more specialized and more prone to individual extinction because of it. If these moons have a more erratic orbit, the Earth's axis of rotation would likely be much more wobbly, increasing the severity of the seasons, but also making them less consistent. Ice ages would be more frequent, shorter lived but of greater intensity. Weather patterns would be more erratic and of greater severity.. If the moons' orbits were too erratic, they would eventually collide, or one (or both) be flung out of Earth’s orbit. A collision essentially end any life on Earth, or at least the vast majority. Losing both moons could also mean the end of life on Earth, but in a more gradual way. Adding more, similarly sized moons would only increase these effects by orders of magnitude.

as such nothing would happen. but there could be one possible thing that the earth would stop rotating bit early than it would with one moon in its orbiti meant, the Moon's orbit (its circular path around the Earth) is indeed getting larger, at a rate of about 3.8 centimeters per year. (The Moon's orbit has a radius of 384,000 km.) I wouldn't say that the Moon is getting closer to the Sun, specifically, though--it is getting farther from the Earth, so, when it's in the part of its orbit closest to the Sun, it's closer, but when it's in the part of its orbit farthest from the Sun, it's farther away. The reason for the increase is that the Moon raises tides on the Earth. Because the side of the Earth that faces the Moon is closer, it feels a stronger pull of gravity than the center of the Earth. Similarly, the part of the Earth facing away from the Moon feels less gravity than the center of the Earth. This effect stretches the Earth a bit, making it a little bit oblong. We call the parts that stick out "tidal bulges." The actual solid body of the Earth is distorted a few centimeters, but the most noticable effect is the tides raised on the ocean. Now, all mass exerts a gravitational force,  and the tidal bulges on the Earth exert a gravitational pull on the Moon. Because the Earth rotates faster (once every 24 hours) than the Moon orbits (once every 27.3 days) the bulge tries to "speed up" the Moon, and pull it ahead in its orbit. The Moon is also pulling back on the tidal bulge of the Earth, slowing the Earth's rotation. Tidal friction, caused by the movement of the tidal bulge around the Earth, takes energy out of the Earth and puts it into the Moon's orbit, making the Moon's orbit bigger (but, a bit pardoxically, the Moon actually moves slower!). The Earth's rotation is slowing down because of this. One hundred years from now, the day will be 2 milliseconds longer than it is now. This same process took place billions of years ago--but the Moon was slowed down by the tides raised on it by the Earth. That's why the Moon always keeps the same face pointed toward the Earth. Because the Earth is so much larger than the Moon, this process, called tidal locking, took place very quickly, in a few tens of millions of years. Many physicists considered the effects of tides on the Earth-Moon system. However, George Howard Darwin (Charles Darwin's son) was the first person to work out, in a mathematical way, how the Moon's orbit would evolve due to tidal friction, in the late 19th century. He is usually credited with the invention of the modern theory of tidal evolution. So that's where the idea came from, but how was it first measured? The answer is quite complicated, but I've tried to give the best answer I can, based on a little research into the history of the question. There are three ways for us to actually measure the effects of tidal friction. * Measure the change in the length of the lunar month over time. This can be accomplished by examining the thickness of tidal deposits preserved in rocks, called tidal rhythmites, which can be billions of years old, although measurements only exist for rhythmites that are 900 million years old. As far as I can find (I am not a geologist!) these measurements have only been done since the early 90's. * Measure the change in the distance between the Earth and the Moon. This is accomplished in modern times by bouncing lasers off reflectors left on the surface of the Moon by the Apollo astronauts. Less accurate measurements were obtained in the early 70's. * Measure the change in the rotational period of the Earth over time. Nowadays, the rotation of the Earth is measured using the Very Long Baseline Interferometry, a technique using many radio telescopes a great distance apart. With VLBI, the positions of quasars (tiny, distant, radio-bright objects) can be measured very accuarately. Since the rotating Earth carries the antennas along, these measurements can tell us the rotation speed of the Earth very accurately. However, the change in the Earth's rotational period was first measured using eclipses, of all things. Astronomers who studied the timing of eclipses over many centuries found that the Moon seemed to be accelerating in its orbit, but what was actually happening was the the Earth's rotation was slowing down. The effect was first noticed by Edmund Halley in 1695, and first measured by Richard Dunthorne in 1748--though neither one really understood what they were seeing. I think this is the earliest discovery of the effect.

Lets take a case of two moons. The idea of an Earth with two moons has been a science fiction staple for decades. More recently, real possibilities of an Earth with two moons have popped up. The properties of the Moon’s far side has many scientists thinking that another moon used to orbit the Earth before smashing into the Moon and becoming part of its mass. Since 2006, astronomers have been tracking smaller secondary moons that our own Earth-Moon system captures; these metre-wide moons stay for a few months then leave. But what if the Earth actually had a second permanent moon today? How different would life be? Astronomer and physicist Neil F. Comins delves into this thought experiment, and suggests some very interesting consequences.  Our Earth-Moon system is unique in the solar system. The Moon is 1/81 the mass of Earth while most moons are only about 3/10,000 the mass of their planet. The size of the Moon is a major contributing factor to complex life on Earth. It is responsible for the high tides that stirred up the primordial soup of the early Earth, it’s the reason our day is 24 hours long, it gives light for the variety of life forms that live and hunt during the night, and it keeps our planet’s axis tilted at the same angle to give us a constant cycle of seasons. A second moon would change that. For his two-mooned Earth thought experiment, Comins proposes that our Earth-Moon system formed as it did — he needs the same early conditions that allowed life to form — before capturing a third body. This moon, which I will call Luna, sits halfway between the Earth and the Moon. Luna’s arrival would wreak havoc on Earth. Its gravity would tug on the planet causing absolutely massive tsunamis, earthquakes, and increased volcanic activity. The ash and chemicals raining down would cause a mass extinction on Earth. But after a few weeks, things would start to settle. Luna would adjust to its new position between the Earth and the Moon. The pull from both bodies would cause land tides and volcanic activity on the new moon; it would develop activity akin to Jupiter’s volcanic moon Io. The constant volcanic activity would make Luna smooth and uniform, as well as a beautiful fixture in the night sky. The Earth would also adjust to its two moons, giving life a chance to arise. But life on a two-mooned Earth would be different. The combined light from the Moon and Luna would make for much brighter nights, and their different orbital periods will mean the Earth would have fewer fully dark nights. This will lead to different kinds of nocturnal beings; nighttime hunters would have an easier time seeing their prey, but the prey would develop better camouflage mechanisms. The need to survive could lead to more cunning and intelligent breeds of nocturnal animals. Humans would have to adapt to the challenges of this two-mooned Earth. The higher tides created by Luna would make shoreline living almost impossible — the difference between high and low tides would be measured in thousands of feet. Proximity to the water is a necessity for sewage draining and transport of goods, but with higher tides and stronger erosion, humans would have to develop different ways of using the oceans for transfer and travel. The habitable area of Earth, then, would be much smaller. The measurement of time would also be different. Our months would be irrelevant. Instead, a system of full and partials months would be necessary to account for the movement of two moons. Eventually, the Moon and Luna would collide; like the Moon is now, both moons would be receding from Earth. Their eventual collision would send debris raining through Earth’s atmosphere and lead to another mass extinction. The end result would be one moon orbiting the Earth, and life another era of life would be primed to start.

Difficult to fully answer this. It depends on what size of moon your are talking about. The most important this to note about the Earth/Moon system is how different it is to most of the other planets in the relative size of the moon to it's parent planet. Almost every other planet in our solar system has moons that are very small compared to the parent body; you can almost think of the Earth/moon as a dual planet. I think the very size of our moon precludes any other large secondary moon as I don't think a secondary moon could exist in a stable orbit, unless it was a small moon and much further out. In that case it would have very little affect on the Earth, beyond being a very bright object in the sky. The moons of Mars are in fact rather like this. Mars has two moons, but they are quite small, and I don't think they'd appear as moonlike discs in the Martian sky. How would a small moon affect the Earth? It might affect animal behaviour to some extent, but tidal forces would be negligable - if not our present large moon would tend to either pull it in to impact on the Earth or the primary moon, or more likely eject it from Earth's orbit. A similar fate of ejection would probably befall any small distant moon as well, as will also probably happen to our existing moon in the very distant future. Of course the earth could have formed with two small moons like Mars has. These could exit in Earth orbit, but would not exert the tidal forces that our current moon does, and nor could they help stabilise the Earth's rotation in the way our current moon does either. Life on Earth it it took off at all would evolve very differently in such a situation. There could be a sweet-state with a couple of medium sized moons in stable orbits, but the chances of this happening would be quite small. However the universe is a big place so maybe somewhere out there there are planetary systems like this.

What would be different if the earth had multiple moons? There would be huge differences in the planet’s climate history and life may never have developed here, or may have developed and gone extinct. Our large moon keeps the Earth steady on its axis limiting the range of temperature variations with seasons. If the axis was able to flip to point the poles at the Sun (as on Uranus), half the planet would fry in continuous sunlight for nearly half the year, while the other hemisphere froze. The giant impact (hypothesised) which formed the Earth-Moon system, mixed the rocks of the Earth and the material which formed the moon into a molten mass, with masses of debris raining down on Earth. Residual heat from this remains in the core. The large moon in a very low orbit, created massive tides once things cooled enough for there to be liquid surface water. and at that time the Earth was spinning very fast from the oblique collision, making a day only about 5 hours long. It would not be possible to have multiple large moons in stable orbits, so with only small moons, the entire climate history and geological history of the planet would be different.

You don’t specify, but I assume you mean fairly substantial bodies akin to the existing moon? Two moons, unless they had similar mass, and the same orbit, would have significant effect on the tidal systems that interact on the oceans on earth, and which cause ‘ground tides’ on the moon. Difficult to predict the extent of these, without computing a potential size, mass, and orbit, but if the orbits were NOT the same (i.e., one moon each side of the earth), the tides would be very variable, as gravitational attraction would combine when they were close together in the sky. Other effects might include increased seismic activity, extremes of nighttime luminosity, not to mention interactions between the moons, which could be cataclysmic, possibly even leading to ‘rings’ a la Saturn around the Earth. Our moon is, in fact, intrinsically effective to the Earth. Loosing it, or varying it (or adding another), would inevitably bring unanticipated change to the Earth, and to life on Earth. rafe

It’s a fun thought experiment, but so much would depend on the sizes of the moons. Assuming the combined weight would be similar to what our single moon weighs or less, the effects wouldn’t be terribly drastic. Tides would be much more complicated, obviously, and two moons could possibly affect plate tectonics, leaving Earth’s crust even more dynamic than it is now. There is a theory that without our single large moon to create tidal pools life would not have arisen on Earth, but this is largely discounted. Today most theories suggest that life arose around deep sea vents long before migrating closer to the surface where solar radiation would have destroyed most early life forms. If this was the case, life might actually have started sooner on a world with two moons since there would likely be more thermal springs, but the truth of th ematter is, until we find life on a world with multiple satellites we may never know with certainty.

As someone living on Earth, I would hope that they are either very low mass and/or very well separated (as is the case for known planets with multiple moons). If not, there’s a very high likelihood that at some point the moons’ orbits will become chaotic and unstable (see the Three-body problem), eventually leading to one of two outcomes: (1) One moon being flung out, while the second moon is flung down, crashing into Earth. (2) That the two moons collide, scatting vast amount of rock in all directions - a large fraction of which will fall on Earth. Either way, it does not end well for life on Earth. The tides on Earth would definitely be affected by the presence of other moons, because the Moon (and also the Sun) is the reason why we experience tides at all. If they were many moons around Earth, the amplitude of the tides might be smaller or larger, since the effects of each other could partially cancel out or add up. There could also be more than two high tides per day, and the cycle of the tides could be less regular than it is. If Earth had more moons, there would also be more solar eclipses. These two things would probably be the more noticeable effects. That's because the seasons and the variation of temperature over the course of the year are caused by the orbit of the Earth around the Sun, and the fact that the Earth's rotation axis is tilted. Unless the presence of more moons could affect one of these, we shouldn't notice any chages in the course of the seasons. As for our body cycles, there are no scientific theories relating them to the presence of the Moon. What would happen if Earth had more than one moon? (Intermediate)

This was my answer to a similar earlier question, “What would be the effects of an Earth-like planet having three moons?” Let’s just start by saying that the effects would be… *interesting*. Assuming that the three moons are of different sizes, distances, and orbital periods, volcanic activity would be drastically increased (see Jupiter’s moon Io for an idea of how and why). Tides would be similarly interesting, especially when the three moons were in alignment and the mother of all king tides came crashing in. Those are just the first two things that come to mind, but it would definitely make life more challenging! Note that in my hypothetical, I made the moons all different sizes, distances, and orbital periods, because that’s the likely scenario that would allow three moons (or two, or nine, or thirty-seven…) to stay separate and not crash into each other. The gravitational effects would be amazing to watch, and even more amazing to try to predict, as the moons orbited and got into opposition and conjunction in various combinations.
